Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Enhanced light detection and ranging imaging by advanced signal processing
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is related to the wide range of applications of light detection and ranging (LiDAR). LiDAR sensors mounted on robots and vehicles are a key component in sensing their environment. With initial applications in automated vehicles, advanced driver assistant systems and fully automated vehicles in the future can potentially reduce the number of accidents caused by inattentive drivers or avoid accidents altogether. Airborne LiDAR allows for 3D mapping of the earth's surface as well as canopy and buildings. This information can be used in insurance, mining, construction planning and other industries. There are also homeland security and defense applications which can benefit from improved models of the environment when operating in hostile. The overall domestic LiDAR market is currently growing rapidly with greater demand for both general and advanced LiDAR signal processing.

This I-Corps project aims at harnessing the properties of light particles (photons) for more accurate light detection and ranging (LiDAR) detection. LiDAR sensors use short laser pulses and record the travel time of photons upon reflection by objects. This travel time is proportional to the distance traveled and therefore allows for 3D imaging of the surroundings. Effects such as ambient light, scene reflectivity, and complex inter-reflections in the scene can significantly degrade the quality of the derived images. New signal processing algorithms model these effects on the received photon stream and therefore allow for higher quality scene estimation. Depth information is fused with another property of photons, the wavelength, which encodes the color of the reflected object. Both color and depth information allow for a realistic image of the environment.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our technology for improved 3D remote sensing provides novel capabilities that are not provided by existing imaging modalities. It could potentially serve a large variety of applications from autonomous driving, to security and disaster response.

We participated in the educational I-Corp activities, including online and in person seminars and developed a business canvas to identify and develop the components important for a successful business. We conducted over 100 customer interviews and gained valuable knowledge about customer needs in relevant product areas. This set of interviews allowed us to obtain initial information about potential markets and product directions. We have participated in 6 conferences and professional meetings and established important contacts in relevant industries. The knowledge from these meetings has also informed our future academic research plans yielding hopefully more impactful results in the future.

Our product enhances 3D remote sensing and imaging capabilities and represents a platform technology that has many potential markets and applications and we will conduct more market research in the coming months to explore more of them. Besides this initial market exploration, we have derived large educational benefits. The entrepreneurial lead in the project is planning to continue commercialization efforts and has participated in further education and fundraising events. We have continued to perform customer interviews and currently have talked to over 160 individuals in relevant positions in industry.

Intellectual Merritt: The proposed technology represents a platform technology providing new capabilities that differ significantly from what is possible using current devices. That makes the customer discovery process for out method particularly complex as there are many potential customers and it is not easy to envision how they would use our technology without an in-depth understanding of their requirements. Engaging in customer discovery and business development for this project is therefore interesting from a commercialization and an educational point of view.

Broader Impacts: 3D imaging and remote sensing have applications in vehicle navigation, virtual reality, military intelligence, aerial imaging, and many other areas, Successful technology transfer of our method will drive further hardware development and drive new applications. Vehicle safety, autonomous driving, infrastructure assessment, and work space safety are just a few multi billion dollar markets that can benefit from improved 3D imaging methods.


Last Modified: 07/01/2020
Modified by: Andreas U Velten
